docs.lead_paragraph: Thirteen clinics across Texas were forced to stop performing abortions because they did not meet the standards of a hospital-style surgery center, as now mandated by law.

headline.main: Texas Women Forced to Reassess After New Ruling on Abortions
headline.print_headline: Texas Women Forced to Reassess After New Ruling on Abortions

docs.abstract: Staff and patients at 13 clinics across Texas that were forced to stop performing abortions under new law struggle to reassess how and where they can receive procedure; federal appeals court had ruled that all clinics in state must meet building and staffing standards of hospital-style surgery center.
docs.snippet: Thirteen clinics across Texas were forced to stop performing abortions because they did not meet the standards of a hospital-style surgery center, as now mandated by law.

byline.original: By LAURA TILLMAN and ERIK ECKHOLM

docs.lead_paragraph: Recent cases in New Jersey and Brooklyn highlight how online communications have blurred boundaries between students and teachers.

headline.main: Abuse Cases at 2 Schools, With Technology at the Root
headline.print_headline: Abuse Cases at 2 Schools: Technology Was at Root

docs.abstract: Two latest cases of child sexual abuse allegations at schools in Maplewood, NJ, and Brooklyn, NY, underscore how modern technology has blurred boundaries between teachers and students; alleged abusers were teachers who seemed more like friends; and both groomed the students using text messages; social media can also make sexual misconduct easier to prosecute.
docs.snippet: Recent cases in New Jersey and Brooklyn highlight how online communications have blurred boundaries between students and teachers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Abortion-rights lawyers are predicting "a showdown" at the U.S. Supreme Court after federal appellate judges allowed full implementation of a law that has closed more than 80 percent of Texas' abortion clinics.

headline.main: Tough Texas Abortion Law May Head to Supreme Court
headline.print_headline: Tough Texas Abortion Law May Head to Supreme Court

docs.snippet: Abortion-rights lawyers are predicting "a showdown" at the U.S. Supreme Court after federal appellate judges allowed full implementation of a law that has closed more than 80 percent of Texas' abortion clinics.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a medical first, a woman in Sweden has given birth after receiving a womb transplant, the doctor who performed the pioneering procedure said Friday.

headline.main: Medical First: Baby Born to Woman Who Got New Womb
headline.print_headline: Medical First: Baby Born to Woman Who Got New Womb

docs.snippet: In a medical first, a woman in Sweden has given birth after receiving a womb transplant, the doctor who performed the pioneering procedure said Friday.

docs.abstract: A collection of everything published in The Times about young people this month, all in one spot.
docs.snippet: A collection of everything published in The Times about young people this month, all in one spot.

docs.lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma doctor who performs nearly half the state's abortions filed a lawsuit Thursday to block a law that would require clinics to have a physician with admitting privileges at a nearby hospital present when an abortion is performed.

headline.main: Oklahoma Abortion Provider Sues Over New Law
headline.print_headline: Oklahoma Abortion Provider Sues Over New Law

docs.snippet: An Oklahoma doctor who performs nearly half the state's abortions filed a lawsuit Thursday to block a law that would require clinics to have a physician with admitting privileges at a nearby hospital present when an abortion is performed.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Liberian man infected with Ebola who brought the disease to the United States will be prosecuted when he returns home for lying on his airport screening questionnaire, Liberian authorities said Thursday.

headline.main: Liberia to Prosecute Man Who Brought Ebola to US
headline.print_headline: Liberia to Prosecute Man Who Brought Ebola to US

docs.snippet: The Liberian man infected with Ebola who brought the disease to the United States will be prosecuted when he returns home for lying on his airport screening questionnaire, Liberian authorities said Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: An Ohio woman has sued a Chicago-area sperm bank after she became pregnant with sperm donated by a black man instead of a white man as she and her partner had intended.

headline.main: White Ohio Woman Sues Over Sperm From Black Donor
headline.print_headline: White Ohio Woman Sues Over Sperm From Black Donor

docs.snippet: An Ohio woman has sued a Chicago-area sperm bank after she became pregnant with sperm donated by a black man instead of a white man as she and her partner had intended.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus on Thursday urged his party to step past its criticism of President Barack Obama and start rallying behind "unifying goals" it would pursue if voters give the GOP more control over the government after next month's midterm elections.

headline.main: RNC Chair: GOP Ready to Lead
headline.print_headline: RNC Chair: GOP Ready to Lead

docs.snippet: Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus on Thursday urged his party to step past its criticism of President Barack Obama and start rallying behind "unifying goals" it would pursue if voters give the GOP more control over the government...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a program offering sexually active teenagers in St. Louis free birth control, pregnancy and abortion rates were less than a quarter of those of such teenagers nationally.

headline.main: A Study Bolsters a Call to Use Long-Acting Contraceptives
headline.print_headline: A Study Bolsters a Call to Use Long-Acting Contraceptives

docs.abstract: Study in New England Journal of Medicine examines results of program in St Louis that counseled teenage girls and provided them with free contraception, including long-acting methods like intrauterine devices and hormonal implants; relates that girls who participated in program had less than a quarter of the annual pregnancy, birth and abortion rates of teenage girls nationally.
docs.snippet: In a program offering sexually active teenagers in St. Louis free birth control, pregnancy and abortion rates were less than a quarter of those of such teenagers nationally.
